section.title: Expression States
section.para: During execution of an expression, it is either active, passive or killed. An active expression will eventually make a site call or publish a value without receiving a response from a site. A passive expression waits for response from sites or functions it has called; it can not take any steps without receiving a response from a site. A killed expression has been terminated because of a pruning combinator; so, it can take no further steps. Expression G is killed in F <x< G if G has published; a component of a killed expression is killed.

There are three passive states: pending, blocked and halted. A pending expression will definitely receive a response from some called site (or function), a blocked expression may receive a response, and a halted expression will never receive a response.
The transitions among the states are as follows:

listitem.para: An active or passive expression may be killed. A killed expression stays killed.
An active expression may transit to any passive state.
A pending expression definitely transits to active eventually.
A blocked expression may transit to another passive state, pending or halted.
A halted expression stays halted unless is killed.
